ğŸš€ What is DocuLift?

DocuLift is a PDF processing dashboard that automates manual data entry tasks using computer vision and OCR. Built with Python's Dash framework, it enables users to extract structured data from scanned PDF forms in seconds â€” replacing hours of repetitive work.

The tool is designed for teams who deal with large volumes of form-based documents and need a fast, visual way to annotate and process data â€” whether for contracts, surveys, or regulatory paperwork.

âš™ï¸ How It Works
  • Upload PDFs from a selected folder using a clean, browser-based UI.
  • Select Detection Type: Choose between circle or square detection for form elements.
  • Box Annotate Elements: Use the interface to draw boxes around questions, text labels, or image areas.
  • Classify Regions: Tag selections as Question, Text, or Image using dropdowns.
  • Review or Process in Bulk: Export annotations or apply them across all files in a folder.
ğŸ§  Why It Matters

Data teams often spend days manually transcribing PDF content into structured spreadsheets. DocuLift eliminates this bottleneck by letting users annotate visual elements once and then apply those annotations across multiple files. The result is faster processing, fewer errors, and consistent extraction across documents.

This was particularly useful in internal test runs where we reduced a 2-week data entry workload to under 2 hours using automation â€” all without writing a single line of code in the interface.

ğŸ› ï¸ Built With
  • Dash (Plotly) â€“ For interactive UI components
  • Pytesseract â€“ OCR engine for reading scanned text
  • OpenCV â€“ For shape detection and visual annotation
  • PIL â€“ Image processing and display
  • Pandas â€“ Data wrangling and Excel export
ğŸ“ Sample Use Case

Imagine a client delivers a set of 100 scanned questionnaires. With DocuLift, an analyst can visually identify the relevant sections (e.g. "Question 1", "Contract Number", signature blocks), tag them once, and then apply the extraction logic across the entire batch. The final result is a structured spreadsheet containing all the values â€” ready for analysis or storage.
